Award.AwardTitle: TUES: Integrating Biofuels Education into Chemical Engineering Curriculum to Prepare Competent Engineers and Researchers for Renewable and Sustainable Energy Solutions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The project is creating educational materials that systematically integrate bio-fuel technology into the undergraduate chemical engineering curriculum. As a part of this effort, the investigators are implementing and evaluating web-based teaching strategies in order to improve student engagement and learning. Specifically, they are creating a set of comprehensive, flexible classroom and web-based modules that can be integrated easily into current chemical engineering curricula and adopted by other educators. Each classroom learning module contains: links to commonly used textbooks for easy integration; different levels of learning objectives based on Bloom's Taxonomy; background information including motivation, process introduction, a discussion of related fundamental principles and concepts; example problems and solutions; a summary; links to web module that will promote active learning and student engagement; homework problems at different difficulty levels; and comprehensive, open-ended design problems. Materials and results are being disseminated through posting on a project website and on a website for sharing material among chemical engineering faculty members (the CACHE site); through presentations at AICHE and ASEE meetings; through papers submitted to archived journals; and through a targeted outreach effort to chemical engineering faculty members at other universities. Evaluation efforts include both a review of the material by faculty members, students and industrial practitioners, and the use of student surveys, focus groups, and the SLAG instrument under the direction of an independent evaluator from one of the participating institutions' teaching and learning centers. Broader impacts involve the dissemination of the instructional materials, particularly through the CACHE site and the targeted outreach to faculty members at other sites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this project is to create educational materials that systematically integrate biofuels technology into undergraduate chemical engineering curriculum. To achieve the project goal, the following three tasks were planned:  (1) to develop biofuels classroom learning modules; (2) to implement and validate advanced instructional strategies for supporting student learning via self-paced web learning modules; (3) to integrate biofuels learning modules into chemical engineering core courses.

All tasks were completed as planned. Classroom modules were developed for Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics course that cover the following four topics: heat effects; thermodynamic properties of fluids, vapor liquid equilibrium, and Solution thermodynamics. Classroom modules were developed for Chemical Reaction Engineering course that cover the following topics: mole balances; conversion and reactor sizing; rate law; stoichiometry and isothermal reactor design. All classroom learning modules can be easily integrated into existing chemical engineering curricula. The key components of each module are: learning objectives, background information, example problems and solution, as well as homework and design problems. The modular and extensible nature of the learning material will enable instructors to easily select, share, expand, and modify the materials to fit students with various learning capabilities and career goals. At Tuskegee University, the classroom modules have been integrated into two classes: CENG350 Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics II and CENG360 Chemical Engineering Reaction Engineering. Students’ feedbacks have been overwhelmingly positive.

The project website (www.biofuelsAcademy.org) is an integral part of the project. All classroom and web modules are shared through the project website. The web modules are designed to address different learning styles, and thereby to enhance students’ engagement in active learning.

On the project website, a comprehensive glossary with more than 800 terms have been created to give students (and general public) a quick reference tool that explain, mostly in simple layman’s language, the terms used in the biofuel technology. At the same time, chemistry and chemical engineering details are included to make them chemical engineering oriented. To the best of our knowledge, this is the most comprehensive glossary of biofuels on the web. Numerous web learning modules were created on various biofuel processes and equipments, which is the largest collection of such learning resources on the web. In addition, visual encyclopedia for over 50 different types of equipments typically used in biofuels processes have been created, including conveyor, hopper, dryer, gasifier, etc. Animated process videos (with narrations) have been developed for different types of gasifiers and Fischer-Tropsch reactors, as well as various biofuels processes, including fermentation, pyrolysis, combustion, liquefaction, etc. Numerous video clips developed by other organizations and institutions are also shared on the project website.

To reach a broader audience, we have also shared the videos created for the project on YouTube. A channel named Biofuels Edu was created to host all videos. The video clips have been viewed more than 297,000 times, and they have received many good comments from the viewer such as the following: “The most straightforward explanation I've seen so far.  Thanks !!!”

Over the course of the project, 32 undergraduate students and 3 graduate students have been trained. Among them, 28 are African Americans and 12 are females.
